EXECUTIVE SUMMARY
RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN
for
Odom?s Tennessee Pride Country Sausage, Inc.

June 16, 2004


I.    Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

Odom?s Tennessee Pride Country Sausage, Inc has a long established policy requiring its staff and management to undertake those measures and activities necessary to ensure the safety of its employees, contractors, visitors and neighbors from harm associated with its operations.  With respect to the potential exposure to anhydrous ammonia contained in the refrigeration system at the Madison, Tennessee facility, appropriate monitoring, maintenance and upgrade of all system equipment will be performed in a timely manner to prevent the release of ammonia from the system.  That policy also limits operation and maintenance of the system to appropriately trained and qualified personnel only.

In the event of a release, Odom?s staff trained to provide emergency response will respond immediately to stop, control and mitigate any release.  Notification of a release will be made to appropriate outside agencies and emergency response organizations.

II.    Source and Substances Handled

The stationary source consists of a two-stage mechanical refrigeration system that employs anhydrous ammonia.  The system contains approximately 11,750 pounds of the material.

III.    General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical Specific Prevention Steps

The facility implements an ongoing inspection and maintenance program to minimize the potential for malfunction/failure of the refrigeration system components that could potentially result in a release of ammonia.  In addition, a computer based system is used to continuously monitor the components of the refrigeration system and ensure that they are operated within the appropriate limits.  The computer based system can automatically shutdown portions of the system as conditions dictate.  In addition, maintenance staff inspects and check key components of the system on

a routine basis to identify conditions that might compromise system integrity.  Odom?s also has an outside agency inspect the system and their risk management and release prevention programs on an annual basis.

Chemical specific release prevention steps include ongoing monitoring of the operation, installation of protective barriers to minimize the potential to physical damage to system components and removing equipment from service when not needed.

IV.    Five Year Accident History

There have been no reportable accidents involving the anhydrous ammonia system during the last five years.

V.    Emergency Response Program

Odom?s maintains a staff onsite that includes personnel appropriately trained to respond to malfunctions and releases of anhydrous ammonia.  They also maintain emergency response equipment, including personal protective equipment, tools, self-contained breathing equipment, and a carbon dioxide neutralization system that may be used to respond to potential releases.  Facility staff routinely coordinates with the local emergency response organizations to ensure that outside responders are familiar with the facility hazards, layout, etc.

VI.    Planned Changes to Improve Safety

Odom?s continues to review and update its programs, personnel training and process equipment to improve its reliability and safety.  No specific changes are planned at this time beyond routine upgrades of equipment.
